keyTakeAways: A cable that snapped in the Glória funicular in Lisbon failed to meet safety specifications set by the operator CARRIS.
The cable was not certified to carry passengers and had structural flaws, contributing to the crash that killed at least 16 people.

The preliminary investigation by the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) identified serious failures in cable integrity, maintenance practices, and brake systems.
Maintenance tasks were falsely marked as completed, and the maintenance plan was recorded as compliant despite not being properly executed.
Eyewitnesses described the crash as chaotic, with one man named Bruno describing the car as 'completely out of control' and a loud bang followed by smoke.
The final report is scheduled for release next year, and the interim findings are described as preliminary and not conclusive.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A deadly crash on the Glória funicular in Lisbon, Portugal, in September 2025, which killed at least 16 people and injured several others, was linked to a steel cable that failed to meet safety specifications set by the operator CARRIS. Preliminary findings from the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) indicate serious flaws in the cable, maintenance records, and brake systems. Maintenance tasks were falsely marked as completed, and the maintenance plan was recorded as compliant despite non-compliance. Eyewitnesses, including a man named Bruno, described the crash as sudden and chaotic. The interim report is not final, and a full final report is expected to be released next year.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
